Award.AwardTitle: Eliciting the Type Space in Extensive-Form Game Forms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Game theory provides predictions of how individuals behave in strategic settings (`games'). It has an enormous range of applicability, from competition between firms to the evolution of a population of microorganisms. But its predictions stem from very strong assumptions on peoples' beliefs, preferences, and rationality. Recent laboratory evidence has shown that the standard predictions are often inaccurate, and several new theories have been proposed as replacements for the standard theory. But almost all existing data comes only from looking at the strategies chosen. The principal investigator proposes to dig deeper by eliciting information about how people think when playing these games. By gaining a better understanding of the underlying thought processes, more accurate game-theoretic models can be built. In addition to this research, the principal investigator will invite high school students to campus (particularly from under-privileged areas) to learn about economics, experiments, and campus life in general.

In the centipede game, there is a pot of money and two players alternatively choose to `pass' or `take'. If they pass, the pot grows and the other player gets to pass or take. If they take, then they take a large fraction of the pot, the other player gets a small fraction, and the game ends. If nobody takes after 't' periods, they split the large pot equally. Backwards induction arguments predict that rational, selfish players will take at every node. But what should a player believe about her opponent if she observes him pass? Should she continue to believe in rationality, as prescribed by the backwards induction argument, or should she now admit the possibility that her opponent is irrational? Different assumptions lead to vastly different predictions about how the game will unfold. Past experiments are not especially insightful in answering these questions because they only observe players' actions. The principal investigator will run experiments in which beliefs about preferences and rationality are elicited during the game as well. This additional data will help to understand how beliefs about rationality evolve, and to develop new, more accurate predictions of how people behave in general sequential-move strategic settings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award funded three projects. The first, entitled "Epistemic Experiments: Utilities, Beliefs, and Irrational Play" is solo-authored by the PI. In our experiments we measure players' utilities and beliefs in the classic "centipede game". We find that many subjects are not selfish, and in fact prefer to pass money to the othr player even when they expect the other player is going to take it on the next turn rather than pass it back (with interest). Interestingly, selfish players know that these selfless types exist, and their presence induces selfish players to pass the pot because they believe it's reasonably likely that their opponent will be selfless and pass it back. Previous research found that most players do pass---and thus, most look to be selfless---but our results show that much of the passing behavior is actually driven by selfish players who are taking advantage of the presence of selfless types.

The second project is "Belief-Free Strategies in Repeated Games with Stochastically-Perfect Monitoring: An Experimental Test", joint with Ritesh Jain (a PhD student at Ohio State) and Ryan Oprea (a professor at UC Santa Barbara). Here we study a repeated prisoner's dilemma game when players cannot observe perfectly the history of their opponent's play. In our experiment we randomly give players complete information about their opponent's actual past play and see whether players wish to revise their strategy after seeing this information. Surprisingly, they rarely revise. In other words, finding out what their opponent has actually been doing has little impact on how a player wishes to proceed in the game. This strongly suggests that they are not using complex strategies that rely on tracking beliefs about the opponent. Rather, they are using simple strategies. But cooperation levels are reasonably high, so these simple strategies still feature enough threat of punishment to prevent the opponent from defecting too regularly.

The third project, entitled "Explaining Conditional Cooperation in Repeated Public Goods Games", is coauthored with Ohio State PhD student Kirby Nielsen. Subjects play a repeated public goods contribution game, but we provide them with data on either the actions or the beliefs of others in a past experiment. For example, we can take a subject who expects others not to contribute much, show them that in fact people tend to contribute a fair amount, and see how that subject updates their play in response. We find that subjects generally do not respond much to this information; knowing that others are more likely to contribute does not make the subject want to contribute more in response.

But in a second treatment we show subjects what others thought their opponents would contribute. And this has an impact: If a subject finds out that others have high expectations, then that subject is more likely to increase her own contribution in response. It is as if the subject does not wish to disappoint the other subjects' expectations.

All three of these projects have been (or shortly will be) written up as working papers available on the PI's website. Each has been presented at numerous conferences worldwide, and the papers will all be submitted for publication at high-ranking journals in economics.

Game theory is used in many fields outside of economics, including political science, sociology, psychology, mathematics, and engineering. Our results are generally applicable to any game theoretic analysis, and particularly germane to any setting in which there is a natural tension between individual incentives and societal goals. Thus, we expect that these results may shape analyses across multiple disciplines.

The award also funded four one-day high-school workshops on experimental economics. In each workshop a group of students is recruited to come to Ohio State's campus to participate in a series of experiments and lectures on some of the core principles of economics. We target students from underrepresented minorities and inner-city schools. The students also get a campus tour and a free lunch at the campus diner. The goal is not only to teach them economic principles and expose them to scientific research, but also to expose them to campus life---both academic and social---so that they may be more likely to pursue post-secondary education and perhaps choose a career in science for themselves.

This award also furthered the professional development of three graduate students and two undergraduates. One of the graduate students (Siqi Pan) is now a professor at the University of Melbourne, and the other two will be entering the academic job market shortly. The undergraduates helped run the high school workshops, which not only exposed them to experimental research, but gave them both administrative and teaching experience. One (Luke Fesko) is now a PhD student in economics at Duke University, and the other (Bethany Cady) is performing her own research with the goal of applying to PhD programs next year.
